title: 108_hr1997
content: The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 2004, also known as "Laci and Conner's Law," amends Title 18 of the United States Code to include a new chapter, "Protection of Unborn Children," which aims to protect unborn children. The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 2004, also known as "Laci and Conner's Law," establishes a separate offense for causing harm to a child in utero. The punishment for this offense is similar to that for causing harm to the mother. It does not require proof of knowledge of the pregnancy or intent to harm the unborn child. If the conduct results in the intentional killing of the unborn child, the offender is punished as if they had killed a human being. The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 2004 establishes a separate offense for causing harm to a child in utero. The punishment for this offense is similar to that for causing harm to the mother. The death penalty shall not be imposed for an offense under this section. The provisions referred to in subsection (a) include various sections of the law related to criminal offenses. The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 2004 establishes a separate offense for causing harm to a child in utero, defining an unborn child as a member of the species homo sapiens at any stage of development in the womb. This section does not permit prosecution for conduct relating to abortion with proper consent, medical treatment of the pregnant woman or her unborn child, or any woman with respect to her unborn child. The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 2004 establishes a separate offense for causing harm to a child in utero, defining an unborn child as a member of the species homo sapiens at any stage of development in the womb. Section 3 of the Military Justice System amends the Uniform Code of Military Justice to include protection for unborn children under Article 119a. The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 2004 creates a separate offense for causing harm to a child in utero, without requiring proof of knowledge or intent. If the conduct intentionally kills the unborn child, different punishments apply under specific sections of the Military Justice System. The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 2004 establishes penalties for intentionally causing harm to a child in utero, with specific punishments under military law for killing or attempting to kill a human being. The death penalty is not allowed for offenses under this act, and certain provisions exclude prosecution for abortion-related conduct with consent, medical treatment, or actions of a pregnant woman towards her unborn child. The term 'unborn child' refers to a member of the species homo sapiens at any stage of development. The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 2004 establishes penalties for causing harm to a child in utero, defining 'child in utero' as a member of the species homo sapiens at any stage of development. A new section, 919a, is added to address the death or injury of an unborn child.
